newsitem.title: UK: Corporate backers raise share of Lloyd's capacity.
newsitem.headline: Corporate backers raise share of Lloyd's capacity.

text.p: Lloyd's of London insurance market said on Tuesday its underwriting capacity for 1997 would be 10.3 billion pounds ($17.16 billion), and that corporate backers would provide a bigger portion of the capacity than in 1996.
Capacity is based on the amount investors, both individuals, known as Names, and corporate backers, are willing to subscribe to the market each year. Capacity in 1996 was 10 billion pounds.
The number of Names investing in Lloyd's will fall next year to 9,972 from 12,798 in 1996 and individual members will supply 5.8 billion pounds or 56 percent of the capacity.
The balance of 4.5 billion, or 44 percent of the capacity, will be supplied by a total of 202 corporate and other limited liability members.

The market Names are still the majority investors in Lloyd's, but are declining in number. They provided 70 percent and corporate members 30 percent of this year's capacity -- the amount Lloyd's can underwrite in terms of premium income.
The insurance market has seen an increasing shift towards corporate backers after a series of unprecedented natural disasters and liability claims brought massive losses for individual members.
Lloyd's said corporate capacity included about 85 million pounds provided by members who are converting into 38 new limited liability vehicles for 1997. ($1=.6003 Pound)
